Books and articles that are accessible to readers without mathematical training
The Human Side of Statistical Consulting

Boen and Zahn sum up their combined experiences as statistical consultants to scientists at a university (Boen) and in industry (Zahn). The book was written for statisticians entering the profession, but it is primarily a book about the psychological relationships among collaborating scientists. The insights and the examples used provide the reader with a very real feel for what the work of a consulting statistician is all about

container-title: Journal of the American Statistical Association
title: Science and statistics
This is an address by George Box, in which he lays out his own philosophy of experimentation and scientific inference. Most of the material is accessible to readers without mathematical training

author.literal: & Sons. Joan Fisher Box is R. A. Fisher's daughter.

title: Fisher, the Life of a Scientist
In this biography of her father, she does an excellent job of explaining the nature and importance of much of his research
many of what he considered to be foolish aspects of American management practices, both in industry and government
The art of learning from experience
This short article explains the development of "the bootstrap" and other forms of computer-intensive resampling, written by the man who invented the bootstrap
Statistical Methods and Scientific Inference
This is her explanation of Deming's work and methods for the nonmathematician
The Grammar of Science

Although some of the examples Pearson used are now outdated, having been superseded by new scientific discoveries, the insights and the bits of well-written philosophy in this book make it a delight to read almost 100 years later. It provides the reader with an excellent example of Pearson's style of writing and thought
